abstracts.cdata!:
This report on the project's
            performance in developing pastoral cooperative associations
            (PCAs), reviews their development, current position, and the
            issues arising in their continued evolution two years after
            project closing. While the project succeeded in establishing
            the PCAs, it was inconsistent over time in its approach to
            the organizations. As a result, the PCAs have not developed
            a clear role and consequent visibility, either locally or
            nationally, and risk becoming insignificant. Given the
            marginality of pastoral livestock producers and their need
            to integrate into the larger economy, this is increasing
            frustration and could undercut other efforts, including
            those of successor projects, unless the lessons learned from
            the project's efforts to support pastoralists are
            heeded. First, instead of a misplaced emphasis on resource
            management systems that attempts to devise and introduce
            improved technologies, priority should be given to actions
            that will help the pastoralists better integrate into the
            larger economy and society. Second future projects should
            consider actions that will foster the growth of a broader
            pattern of local leadership in the communities, actions
            providing an enabling environment for new initiatives and
            the emergence of new cooperative groupings. Third when
            strong local structures for development-oriented activities
            do not exist, a sequenced and process approach to project
            operations is required.
